supportDesc.support:
Folio sheet of paper folded in half to form four quarto pages, with correspondence on 1-3 and address leaf on page 4, then folded in thirds twice more and sealed for posting.
Address leaf bearing the following postmarks: 1) black circular mileage stamp illegible, 2) red double circle Duty stamp reading B
23 AP 23
1821
.
A large 7 denoting the fee for a single-sheet letter has been written in black ink by the postal service across the address leaf.

handNotes.handNote: Red crayon or thick red pencil. Probably a different hand from Mitford's drawing a diagonal line across pages 1-3.
Someone cataloging the letters, apparently other than Mitford, numbered each on page 1. This page one numbered 31.

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice," “sic," and “reg" to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

div.p:
I thank you very much, my ever dear & kind friend, for your good humoured indulgence of my importunate request--I have given you good reason to think me a spoilt child, & perhaps I shall give you still more by a trait peculiar to spoilt children & which though generally regarded as an additional proof of their obstinacy & self will is in reality the tribute they pay to reason in correcting their own unreasonableness. (Do you understand purpled sentence?) In shock after having coaxed and persuaded you to lend me the plaything I wanted, & which you are afraid I shall spoil, nothing is more profitable, than that I may either make no use of it at all--or that I may make the precise use which you point out. Any wayAnyway, I am glad to see these poor letters again (for I do not think that I have ever written any with so little reserve so much con amore) & I promise you to keep them safely for you--not to spoil them--if I can possibly help it in my way--thothough look them over with the view to make a fortune or fool of them if I can,--before I proceed to the gutting process I threatented. Is this making as much amends as I can for my unreasonableness?--As to their mode of conveyance, that which I should much prefer would be your bringing them here (Do come & see me my dear Sir William--but if you would do that--there is a very safe & certain mode of conveyance--Mr. Monck is in town for the Lord Mayor's dinner & returns Wednesday, & if you will have the goodness to send the packet directed to me to his care No. 10 Barton Street, Westminster--it will reach me very safely. Nevertheless as I said before I should greatly rather receive the letters from your own kind hand. It is too long since we have seen you--& as to my going to Town I have no prospect of that this Spring.--You are very saucy with your Hieroglyphics & as much mistaken
as a man can be. You were deceived I hope in the management of your eyes & tongue when you saw Mr. H. (I know that you have seen him.) He says the Lazarus shall be the best picture he has painted yet, but that that shall be a nonentity if he lives to Mitford appears to omit the word "complete" here. those that he will paint in the future. This is the true spirit--Is it not? Tell me what you think of a gala at Richmond which Mr. Hofland has just sent to Somerset House. His wife (one good judge) says that it is excellent--equal to Jerusalem--& Miss James (also a good judge) says that it is detestable--I incline to the latter because I know that Mr. Hofland like many other fine landscape painters fails in figures. But I want your opinion. By the way I must tell you a remarkable circumstance which has just happened to Mrs. Hofland--They have been for many years engaged in a Chancery suit on the expected success of which they have placed great reliance--It has been given in their favor but as the costs are to be paid out of the property not a farthing will come to them. At first however they knew nothing for of this for their solicitor having neglected to write & they heard only from a neighbour that the Chancellor's decree was in their favor & Mrs. Hofland immediately set off for London to learn the particulars--She was quite overcome by what she heard, & was about to mount the outside of the Twickenham Coach to return "all amort" as you must suppose, when recollecting she should save six pence in going by the Richmond Stage--& such a one being at hand, she withdrew her foot although a most respectable woman with her husband at her side offered to make room for her. However she left by the Richmond Coach & saved her six pence--& her life. The Twickenham Coach was overturned an hour after, & that decent woman in whose place she would have sat killed on the spot. The husband had his collar bonecollarbone & a rib broken. This most striking event gave a new & just turn to her thoughts--Miss Jamessays nothing was ever half so pathetic as her manner of detailing it.
Two things in this neighbourhood annoy me very much--First & most Mr. Dickinson--he is really killing himself. Never man had such symptoms of approaching apoplexy, & because he has all his life combated the received theories of medicine especially what he calls the system (which was of no consequence whilst confined to mere speculative harangues) he is now determined to stand by his opinions to the last, & really will rather die by the blood rushes to his head than live by the lancet. Is not this vicious? Has a man any right to take himself out of the world before his time from sheer obstinacy, when all his friends want him to live life merry? Every bodyEverybody has warned him--two physicians to my knowledge & three apothecaries-- & not counting me a quack--but he is absolutely unpersuadable & has made Mr. Dickinson believes he knows more of physic than every oneeveryone else.--The other calamity need not annoy me in the least--but it does nonetheless. You shall hear it. The Duke of Wellington's sons are home for the Eton holidays, & they are every dayeveryday little ale house next door to take lessons in French of a Jew who is lodging there purposely to teach them. "The poor little lads ma'am" said my neighbour the landlord "are kept very strict--they never look up but their tutor corrects them, & there they sit in my parlour from eleven oclocko'clock till half past four & never have a glass of anything." Without sympathasizing very deeply in the last grievance enumerated by my friend taproom, I am quite indignant at the poor little boys being cheated out of their holidays. Learning French from fools when they ought to be playing cricket or stealing bird's nests or doing mischief or doing nothing--beating Napoleon was a joke to this wickedness. The only thing which even looks like the holidays is their mode of conveyance which is generally five in a gig rain or shine--once they came on horseback & then they had a humpbacked boy on a donkey galloping off
them by way of footman to carry their books.

I must finish soon--for I have no frank--Mr. Monck is I suppose Lord-Mayoring & Mr. Palmer has made himself wings & flown away--I have not seen him these six months. Have you heard any thinganything of Lady Madalina?--I have no news of my play yet. Mr. Macready has taken himself out of Town before my friend returned from the circuit--which will likewise delay till June the appearance of my Dramatic Sketches in Baldwin's Magazine.--Adieu my dear friend--If we may hope for the pleasure of seeing you let us know a day or two before. My Father & Mother join in kindest regards & I am always

postscript.p: Pray do come--We shall all be so glad to see you.
